keywords.value: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

byline.original: By The New York Times

articles.snippet: Why should the F.A.A. continue to permit a system prone to going haywire aboard an aircraft?
articles.lead_paragraph: The struggle that the two Lion Air pilots waged with their out-of-control 737 Max 8 aircraft last October was both tenacious and terrifying. A new automated safety feature on the jet designed to prevent stalls instead kept sending the aircraft into a dive. Again and again, the pilots pulled the jet’s nose up, only to have a faulty sensor reverse their actions. For some reason, they couldn’t or didn’t cut off the automation, which ultimately sent the year-old Boeing jet into a steep dive and a crash that would claim 189 lives.
articles.abstract: Why should the F.A.A. continue to permit a system prone to going haywire aboard an aircraft?

The gradual spread of automation through the civil aircraft fleet is a primary reason the accident rate worldwide has fallen from about four accidents per million flights in 1977 to less than 0.4 today. byline.original: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.snippet: Malfunctions caused two deadly crashes. But an industry that puts unprepared pilots in the cockpit is just as guilty.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 29, 2018, Lion Air Flight 610 taxied toward the runway at the main airport in Jakarta, Indonesia, carrying 189 people bound for Bangka Island, a short flight away. The airplane was the latest version of the Boeing 737, a gleaming new 737 Max that was delivered merely three months before. The captain was a 31-year-old Indian named Bhavye Suneja, who did his initial flight training at a small and now-defunct school in San Carlos, Calif., and opted for an entry-level job with Lion Air in 2011. Lion Air is an aggressive airline that dominates the rapidly expanding Indonesian market in low-cost air travel and is one of Boeing’s largest customers worldwide. It is known for hiring inexperienced pilots — most of them recent graduates of its own academy — and for paying them little and working them hard. Pilots like Suneja who come from the outside typically sign on in the hope of building hours and moving on to a better job. Lion Air gave him some simulator time and a uniform, put him into the co-pilot’s seat of a 737 and then made him a captain sooner than a more conventional airline would have. Nonetheless, by last Oct. 29, Suneja had accumulated 6,028 hours and 45 minutes of flight time, so he was no longer a neophyte. On the coming run, it would be his turn to do the flying.
articles.abstract: Malfunctions caused two deadly crashes. But an industry that puts unprepared pilots in the cockpit is just as guilty.

byline.original: By David Gelles

articles.snippet: Boeing’s chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, testified before Congress for the first time since the crashes of two 737 Max jets that killed 346 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Boeing’s chief executive faced the grieving relatives of two deadly crashes of its 737 Max jet at an emotional congressional hearing on Tuesday, as senators pummeled him with questions about whether the company should have grounded the plane before the second accident. At times looking shaken, the executive, Dennis A. Muilenburg, said that if he could do it over again, he would have acted after the first crash, off the coast of Indonesia last October. “If we knew everything back then that we know now, we would have made a different decision,” he testified. He said Boeing officials had asked themselves “over and over” again why they didn’t ground the plane sooner.
